questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

hobby.message: You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?
Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: I suppose you could say that.
Let's just say, it's a night for caution.
Collecting old political literature isn't popular with everyone.
Current events make that even less safe.
Something like that. The wrong book gets dangerous, these days.
My hobby's restoring banned print editions—old political texts, mainly.
Was reorganizing when things got tense at home.
Protests make it harder to keep certain volumes.
I avoid risking anything irreplaceable now.
Bit of a close call, yes. I restore and collect banned political books.
Not the sort of pastime the Council admires.
Spent hours hiding a few after the dossier leaks.
Signal blackouts and compliance checks aren’t ideal for collectors.
Makes reading feel almost illicit.
But it’s hard to give up old routines.
You’re not wrong—I nearly lost half my collection last night.
I collect, annotate, even restore forbidden political writings. It’s an obsession.
Old texts from before the system—some handwritten.
After those dossier leaks, compliance units swept my building.
Spent hours stashing books and scrambling my notes.
BCI flagged my account. Suddenly, every page felt risky.
There’s a thrill in preserving what others erase.
Absolutely dodged more than a headache. I collect and restore banned political literature—every regime’s favorite scapegoat.
Decades-old manifestos, newsprint leaflets, even original censored Council speeches.
Last night, I had covert cleanup duty—dossiers triggered a compliance dragnet in my sector.
Encrypting my annotations, hiding decoys, checking which volumes are still safe.
I can recall entire passages—memory is all that survives when order cracks.
Been at it since my BCI dipped, after I questioned a phrasing order.
Council fears history with good reason; every pamphlet I own tells their secrets.
I almost lost my notes—irreplaceable. Sometimes I think knowledge is more subversive than any protest.
hobby_answer: Still collecting, maybe. Depends who’s asking.
Paper weighs less than suspicion these days.
Watched neighborhoods burn over books before. Now whole archives vanish overnight.
After the dossiers dropped, pages feel heavier in hand.
Literature’s just another risk profile now. Best left unread.
Yeah, still hunting – carefully.
Even a dog-eared pamphlet can get you flagged now.
After last week’s leaks, patrols doubled in my area.
I had to hide half my collection overnight, just in case.
Strange times to be interested in history, isn’t it.
Trust in preservation, not in being seen reading.
I still chase forbidden texts. Harder now than ever.
After the dossiers, sweeps have become bolder.
A neighbor’s place got raided for pamphlets three days ago.
Had to move my collection twice this week.
Reading’s not relaxing when every annotation feels incriminating.
The hunt’s half the thrill, though — especially now.
Old words feel urgent again, you know.
Absolutely. Illegal texts are my currency and comfort.
Saw Directorate teams combing streets two nights ago, right after the dossiers.
I spent hours stashing half my library under the floorboards.
You ever label a banned novel as 'maintenance logs'? It actually works.
I save not just the books, but every note, every revision.
There’s real fear now — they profile collectors like us.
But honestly, surviving the hunt is what keeps me sane.
Censorship’s lost, honestly. Ideas just get smarter at hiding.
Always — it’s a compulsion, really. Family history in samizdat, goes back generations.
After the dossier drop, Directorate flagged my BCI over known ‘subversive interests’.
Had patrols on my block three nights straight, so I rotated storage spots again.
Lost an old edition of Veiko’s Manifest — confiscated, probably gone for good.
Sometimes I transcribe whole paragraphs from memory, just in case.
Annotating is risky now; every scribble’s metadata traces back to me.
I’ve archived banned speeches leaders never even delivered publicly.
Funny thing — the system suppresses, but that just makes the text stronger.
History’s only ever alive when someone tries to erase it. That’s why I keep collecting.
